title.narrative: AfDB, 2019-2022, Jobs for Youth in Africa / YEI MDTF
AfDB, 2019-2022, Jobs for Youth in Africa / YEI MDTF

description.narrative:
The Youth Entrepreneurship and Innovation Multi-Donor Trust Fund (YEI MDTF), established in 2017, is the grant vehicle supporting the ten-year Jobs for Youth in Africa (JfYA) Strategy adopted by the African Development Bank (AfDB). The JfYA Strategy objective is to create 25 million jobs and equipping 50 million youth with employable skills in Africa by 2025. YEI MDTF provides financing to support Bank initiatives regarding youth-led micro, small and medium sized enterprises (MSMEs) in the formal and informal economy with business development services as well as supporting its African member countries in implementing enabling environment reforms conductive to job creation. It adresses three areas: (i) Business Development Services (BDS), including access to finance, to youth-led startups and MSMEs in growth enhancing sectors (mainly Agriculture, Manufacturing, and ICT) targeting those with viable products and sustainable business models leading to growth and job creation; (ii) Research and Studies, and their dissemination, to expand the existing knowledge base on building a reliable African entrepreneurship ecosystem and identify the most efficient and sustainable solutions that can be replicated and scaled at national, regional and continental levels; and (iii) Support to countries' strengthening of the enabling policy and regulatory frameworks conducive to MSME and private sector development including dialogue, and supporting countries to undertake labour and economic reforms through capacity building, transfer of knowledge, best practices and regulatory support.
Available resources are used for funding the acquisition of consultancy services, the provision of training and capacity building, the provision of technical assistance in the preparation of policies and studies, and other technical assistance activities as may be mutually agreed upon between the partner and funders. Eligible recipients of support include formal and informal youth-led startups and MSMEs of which at least 50% are women-led, business development service providers and governments aiming at a strengthened enabling environment for private sector development and youth employment. By supporting youth-led startups and MSMEs with skills development and bringing them into formality, the Trust Fund contributes to increased productive and decent employment, job creation and inclusive growth.

Youth Entrepreneurship and Innovation Multi-Donor Trust Fund (YEI MDTF) är en fond skapad 2017 för biståndsgivare som vill bidra till genomförandet av Afrikanska utvecklingsbankens tioåriga ungdomssysselsättningsstrategi Jobs for Youth in Africa (JfYA). Målet med strategin är att fram till år 2025 skapa 25 miljoner jobb i Afrika och bidra till ytterligare 50 miljoner ungas stärkta kompetens för att möta den afrikanska arbetsmarkandens behov. Fonden bidrar med ekonomiskt stöd för att främja ungdomsledda micro-, små- och medelstora företag inom den formella och informella sektorn genom olika former av affärsutvecklingsinsatser, samt insatser som främjar genomförande av reformer för bättre företagande. De tre fokusområdena är (i) affärsutvecklingsstöd, inklusive ökad tillgång till lån, till ungdomsledda små- och medelstora företag inom sektorer med tillväxtpotenital (huvudsakligen inom jordbruk, tillverkningsindustri samt informations- och kommunikationsteknologi). Stöd riktas mot (i) företag med lönsamma produkter och hållbara affärsmodeller vilka förväntas leda till jobbskapande; (ii) forskning och studier, och spridningen av dessa, med syftet att utveckla den nuvarande kunskapsbasen om afrikanskt entreprenörsskap och att identifiera effektiva och hållbara lösningar som kan replikeras och appliceras på nationell, regional och kontinental nivå; och (iii) stöd för att stärka afrikanska länders privatsektorpolicys och regelverk för små- och medelstora företag samt genomförandet av arbetsmarknads- och ekonomiska reformer genom kapacitetsbyggnad, kunskapsspridning och regleringar.
Tillgängliga medel ska användas för upphandling av konsulttjänster i utbildningssyfte, tekniskt stöd i policyutveckling och för studier samt annan verksamhet som bedöms relevant för måluppfyllelse. Målgruppen är ungdomsledda formella och informella micro-, små- och medelstora företag (varav minst 50% avser kvinnoledda företag), aktörer som bidrar med affärsutvecklingsstöd och regeringar som vill utveckla den privata sektorn och bidra till ökad ungdomssysselsättning. Genom kompetensutveckling och formalisering av ungdomsledda företag bidrar fonden till produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor, fler arbetstillfällen och en inkluderande tillväxt.

The objective of the Jobs for Youth in Africa Strategy (2016-2025) is to create 25 million jobs and equip 50 million youth with employable skills by the end of the strategy period. The overarching impact objective of the Youth Entrepreneurship and Innovation Multi Donor Trust Fund supporting the implementation of the Strategy, is reduced unemployment, vulnerability and poverty among the youth. Directly linked to the Trust Fund's three support areas, the impact objective will be achieved by three outcome objectives: (i) increased access to finance and business survival of youth-led MSMEs who receive BDS (business development services) through the YEI MDTF; (ii) direct jobs created by youth-led MSMEs supported through activities of the YEI MDTF; and (iii) increased knowledge and enabling environment for MSME development. Implementation is based on regional member countries' priorities and interest for participating. The Trust Fund complements other existing financing instruments such as the Affirmative Finance Action for Women in Africa (AFAWA), the Private Sector Facility (PSF) and the African Trade Fund (AfTRA) among others. It also complements the Joint Labour Migration Programme (JLMP) through improved conditions for job creation, thus helping to reduce work related migration on the continent. Initially, i.e. 2019, the activities financed by the Trust Fund will carried out in Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Nigeria, Rwanda, Tanzania and Togo. Extended geographical scope is approved annually by the Bank and supporting donors.

tag.narrative: 8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.

description.narrative: The JfYA strategy objective is the ultimate goal of the YEI MDTF as well as the other AfDB flagship programmes, i.e. the Rural Micro-enterprise Flagship Programme; the Youth Empowering Novel Agri-Business Led Employment Programme (ENABLE); the Agro-Industrialization Pipeline Flagship Programme, and the Skills Enhancement Zone Flagship Programme. These initiatives collectively contribute to creating 25 million jobs and equipping 50 million youth with employable skills by 2025. The examples of progress made in 2019 are mainly based on the YEI MDTF annual narrative report covering 1 January to 31 December 2019 which was submitted to the signatory donors, i.e. Denmark, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway and Sweden. Additional findings will be presented by and discussed with the African Development Bank on December 14, 2020 at the final oversight committee meeting (annual review meeting) of the year. The implementation of planned project activities accelerated considerably in 2019 as a result of previous years fund raising measures and the recruitment of key staff to the core fund team. One such key function is the monitoring and evaluation officer whose responsibility encompasses results monitoring and management. That has consequently improved the prospects for adequate reporting of results which is fundamental for Sweden as well as the other contributing donor countries' continued support. A main focus of the Fund - to promote increased access to business development services (BDS) and finance for youth owned start-ups and MSMEs with the support of Enterprise Support Organizations (ESOs), i.e. business incubators and accelerators, and financial intermediaries such as banks and venture capital funds, has resulted in the strengthened capacity of 1,000 young business owners, including in countries of transition and migration hot spots. 400 MSMEs have been trained further and the capacity building of another 210 MSMEs has commenced. It is expected that at least 40% of the businesses will be provided access to finance on commercial terms as a result of their enhanced capacity. Another 3,000 start-ups and MSMEs are being offered BDS and access to finance in 2020. To further stimulate MSME enterprising in Sub-Saharan Africa, YEI MDTF supports two important financing platforms which promote youth managed enterprising and increased investments in the MSME sector; AgriPitch, and the African Investment Forum. Capacity building support is being offered to ESO organisations in at least two more African countries this year. Furthermore, technical assistance projects are being implemented in collaboration with the governments of Mali, Ghana and Guinea in order to support the enabling environment for increased youth employment - such as business regulatory reforms and social enterprise policies. AfDB is negotiating with the UK for their entering the trust fund with the aim of further expanding the contribution of the enabling environment pillar hence supporting additional government policy reform platforms, a prerequisite for long-term, sustainable employment creation. In 2020, progress has continued and the disbursement of funds has increased significantly as the projects funded by YEI MDTF have both been ongoing and matured for a period of time. Project implementation and the disbursement of project funds is a continued focus in 2021. To reach scale and impact, priority is also made to support the implementation of larger projects. A recent decision has been made to fund the implementation of the USD 4 million G5 SAHEL Project for the Resilience of Youth-led Enterprises in Burkina Faso, Mali, Mauritania, Niger and Chad - Sahel being a focus sub-region for Sweden's Regional Development Cooperation Strategy in Sub-Saharan Africa. The project goal is to contribute to the revival and expansion of youth and women managed MSME activities and build economic resilience as a consequence of the COVID-19 crisis. The donors of YEI MDTF have recommended AfDB to adopt a regional approach, coordinate the project with relevant ongoing initiatives in the Sahel region and investigate whether a similar intervention could be replicated in other sub-regions, such as the Horn of Africa. The Post #Africa Virus Challenge Project, a USD 500,000 intervention aimed at accelerating AfDB's COVID-19 response by promoting rapid and innovative solutions to assist Africa addressing some of the most pressing issues, has in the relatively short time since its start received more than 25,000 applications for support. Out of the "top 100 solutions" submitted, 20 MSMEs have been selected which will consequently receive business development services and small grants to develop sustainable businesses. Yet another initiative; Strengthening the Financing Pillars of the Entrepreneurship Ecosystem in Ghana, a USD 400,000 project, is subject for financial support from the Trust Fund with the goal of fast-tracking the implementation of the national MSME Policy for improving business operating procedures, and access to finance and markets for youth-led MSMEs. It is expected that it will become a model for leveraging larger AfDB projects targeting the business regulatory environment across Africa. AfDB has put a comprehensive reporting system in place that will help collecting and consolidating data from implementing partners and beneficiaries and to inform results tracking regularly. In addition, impact and outcomes data will also be captured during the mid-term evaluation of 2021 and the final evaluations of the Trust Fund.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
